body: ACK 284a969cc082ae3c63ab523f22e71da86ad4ab20 Reviewed, manually tested. Works great!

tested ACK 284a969cc082ae3c63ab523f22e71da86ad4ab20
Test

``` $ touch foo $ git add foo $ git commit -am "Foo → Bar" $ test/lint/lint-git-commit-check.sh The subject line of commit hash 1b6e02448bcced186160815a986d65ca38144940 is followed by a non-empty line. Subject lines should always be followed by a blank line. $ test/lint/lint-git-commit-check.sh 0 $ test/lint/lint-git-commit-check.sh 1 The subject line of commit hash 1b6e02448bcced186160815a986d65ca38144940 is followed by a non-empty line. Subject lines should always be followed by a blank line. ```
utACK 284a969cc082ae3c63ab523f22e71da86ad4ab20

The linter seems to fail in the CI for commit messages without a body, at least it did for me here https://travis-ci.org/github/bitcoin/bitcoin/builds/714296380 and I can not reproduce it locally. Can somebody else confirm this or is able to reproduce this locally?

> The linter seems to fail in the CI for commit messages without a body, at least it did for me here https://travis-ci.org/github/bitcoin/bitcoin/builds/714296380 and I can not reproduce it locally. Can somebody else confirm this or is able to reproduce this locally?

My initial analysis of what caused the failure was wrong so ignore that part. But I think I have found what the issue was and proposed a fix here: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19654

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,27 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+# Copyright (c) 2017-2019 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+#
+# Linter to check that commit messages have a new line before the body
+# or no body at all
+#
+# reference: gist.github.com/agnivade/67b42d664ece2d4210c7
+#
+# WARNING: Using a "+" character in commit messages can result in 
+# improper parsing
+
+export LC_ALL=C
+while read -d "+" -r msg  || [[ -n "$msg" ]]; do
+    n_line=0
+    while IFS= read -r line || [[ -n "$line" ]]; do
+        n_line=$((n_line+1))
+        length=${#line}
+        if [ $n_line -eq 2 ] && [ $length -ne 0 ]; then
+            echo "Your subject line follows a non-empty line. Subject lines should always be followed by a blank line."
+            exit 1
+        fi
+    done < <(echo "$msg")
+done < <(git log origin..HEAD --format=%s%b+)
body:
`$ git log origin..HEAD --format=%s%b+` isn't working for me while testing locally. I get:
```
fatal: ambiguous argument 'origin..HEAD': unknown revision or path not in the working tree.
Use '--' to separate paths from revisions, like this:
'git <command> [<revision>...] -- [<file>...]'
```

+#

+#

+# improper parsing
+
+export LC_ALL=C
+while read -d "+" -r msg  || [[ -n "$msg" ]]; do
+    n_line=0
+    while IFS= read -r line || [[ -n "$line" ]]; do
+        n_line=$((n_line+1))
+        length=${#line}
+        if [ $n_line -eq 2 ] && [ $length -ne 0 ]; then
+            echo "Your subject line follows a non-empty line. Subject lines should always be followed by a blank line."
+            exit 1
+        fi
+    done < <(echo "$msg")
+done < <(git log origin..HEAD --format=%s%b+)
+
+echo "No commit message formatting errors detected."
body:
If successfully passed, you'd want this to exit silently. Following the format of the other linters, I'd suggest replacing this line:
```suggestion
exit ${EXIT_CODE}
```

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,27 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+# Copyright (c) 2017-2019 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+#
+# Linter to check that commit messages have a new line before the body
+# or no body at all
+#
+# reference: gist.github.com/agnivade/67b42d664ece2d4210c7
+#
+# WARNING: Using a "+" character in commit messages can result in 
+# improper parsing
+
+export LC_ALL=C
+while read -d "+" -r msg  || [[ -n "$msg" ]]; do
body:
This "+" idea is clever!  However, I don't think it's one we can live with.  The "+" character is actually used surprisingly often in commit messages.

`git log --grep='+' --oneline | wc -l`
\> 706

Two suggested solutions, if you're looking for somewhere to start
- Try and find a list of valid characters in commit messages, and see if you can use one that isn't in the list.  Maybe "#" would work?  I know that emojis work in commit messages, so maybe this isn't a viable option, but check it out :)
 - Try iterate over each commit, as opposed to getting them all at once.

body:
Check out what this outputs, I don't think it's what you want.
Possibly you're looking for `--format=%B+`, and then see if you can think of a way to deal with the "+" issue.

body:
This message isn't quite right.  Maybe something like one of these is better.

```suggestion
            echo "Your body follows a non-empty line. Subject lines should always be followed by a blank line."
```

```suggestion
            echo "Your subject line is followed by a non-empty line. Subject lines should always be followed by a blank line."
```

body: I changed it to `git log origin/master..HEAD`. My intent is to get the last N commits that have not yet been pushed in a portable way. I did some research and I believe the change that I have made achieves this, but please let me know if not.

@@ -0,0 +1,26 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+#
+# Linter to check that commit messages have a new line before the body
+# or no body at all
+
+export LC_ALL=C
+
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+while IFS= read -r commit_hash  || [[ -n "$commit_hash" ]]; do
+    n_line=0
+    while IFS= read -r line || [[ -n "$line" ]]; do
+        n_line=$((n_line+1))
+        length=${#line}
+        if [ $n_line -eq 2 ] && [ $length -ne 0 ]; then
+            echo "Your body is followed by a non-empty line. Subject lines should always be followed by a blank line."
+            EXIT_CODE=1
+            break
+        fi
+    done < <(git log --format=%B -n 1 "$commit_hash")
+done < <(git log origin/master..HEAD --format=%H)
body: Could make sense to default this to `TRAVIS_COMMIT_RANGE` if available?

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+#
+# Linter to check that commit messages have a new line before the body
+# or no body at all
+
+export LC_ALL=C
+
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+while getopts "?" opt; do
+  case $opt in
+    ?)
+      echo "Usage: $0 [N]"
+      echo "       TRAVIS_COMMIT_RANGE='<commit range>' $0"
+      echo "       $0 -?"
+      echo "Checks unmerged commits, the previous N commits, or a commit range."
+      echo "TRAVIS_COMMIT_RANGE='47ba2c3...ee50c9e' $0"
+      exit ${EXIT_CODE}
+    ;;
+  esac
+done
+
+if [ -z "${TRAVIS_COMMIT_RANGE}" ]; then
+  if [ -n "$1" ]; then
+    TRAVIS_COMMIT_RANGE="HEAD~$1...HEAD"
+  else
+    TRAVIS_COMMIT_RANGE="origin/master..HEAD"
+  fi
+fi
+
+while IFS= read -r commit_hash  || [[ -n "$commit_hash" ]]; do
+    n_line=0
+    while IFS= read -r line || [[ -n "$line" ]]; do
+        n_line=$((n_line+1))
+        length=${#line}
+        if [ $n_line -eq 2 ] && [ $length -ne 0 ]; then
+            echo "The body of commit hash ${commit_hash} is followed by a non-empty line. Subject lines should always be followed by a blank line."
body:
Good idea adding the commit hash!  The grammar still isn't quite what I'd like.

```suggestion
            echo "The subject line of commit hash ${commit_hash} is followed by a non-empty line. Subject lines should always be followed by a blank line."
```
or, if you like it better
```suggestion
            echo "The subject line of commit hash ${commit_hash} is followed by a non-empty line. Please insert a blank line between the subject line and the body of the commit message."
```
